news.title: New Gentoo Linux NVIDIA driver layout

summary.p: Thanks to Arcady Genkin, we now have some nice newly-designed NVIDIA driver/GLX ebuilds for Gentoo Linux. The old ebuild was easy to install but didn't isolate various NVIDIA files from those in /usr/X11R6. These new ebuilds correct this as well as several other problems. To learn how to use these new ebuilds, read Arcady's instructions by clicking on the "full story" below.

section.title: New Gentoo Linux NVIDIA ebuild install instructions

body.p: The NVIDIA kernel driver and GLX ebuild has been upgraded and split into two new, more mature ebuilds. This announcement covers the ebuild changes to and explains the installation and upgrade procedures.

ul.li: The media-gfx/nvidia ebuild was split into two components: media-video/nvidia-kernel and media-video/nvidia-glx. This was done to map to the organisation of the drivers as released by NVIDIA and to ease the kernel upgrade procedure.
The new NVIDIA ebuilds have been moved to a different category, media-video.
The new NVIDIA ebuilds no longer overwrite any of the files installed by xfree86 (x11-base/xfree.) Instead, everything from the media-video/nvidia-glx package now goes into /opt/nvidia.

ol.li: Merge the media-video/nvidia-kernel and media-video/nvidia-glx packages.

Add the following to the Files section of your XF86Config file:
ModulePath "/opt/nvidia/modules" ModulePath "/usr/X11R6/lib/modules"
If you want the NVdriver kernel module to be loaded automatically at boot up, add NVdriver to your /etc/modules.autoload file.
If you had the old media-gfx/nvidia package installed, optionally follow the instructions to unmerge it and restore any files that it clobbered.

body.p: If you're just interested in upgrading to the new packages, you can keep your existing installation as-is. It should be fine as long as you continue to use the NVIDIA drivers.
If you want to restore your /usr/X11R6 directory to its original pristine state, follow these instructions:

ol.li: Restore the files overwritten by it. The easiest way to do this is to remerge x11-base/xfree.
